Award.AwardTitle: A Next Generation Geospace Facility at Millstone Hill
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund continued operation and discovery science with the incoherent scatter radar (ISR) at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s Millstone Hill (MH) Observatory (MHO). The ISR measures backscatter from ionospheric electrons, that is used to recover ion and electron temperatures, densities, winds and constituent abundances 100-1000 km above earth's surface. MHO has a very strong science education and community outreach component, and also curates and distributes an NSF community database.

Research activities under this award include sub-auroral magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling; ionosphere-thermosphere coupling during geospace storms; long-term change in the ionosphere and thermosphere; whole atmosphere coupling; and meteoroid studies using software radar methods.

The ISR is in the process of transitioning to a new, low cost digital architecture that will uniquely provide continuous, long-term, vertical profiles of ionospheric parameters. This new capability will substantially increase observations of ionospheric and thermospheric disturbances, and will be showcased over the period of performance of the award.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award provided facilities and operations support for the Millstone Hill Geospace Facility and the Millstone Hill UHF research radar, for a program of investigations of upper atmospheric morphology and dynamics and the near-Earth space environment coordinated with community requests and initiatives. Operations and analysis activities have been focused on the geospace processes coupling the various regions of Earth?s upper atmosphere.

Experiments were centered around the community-driven World Day observing periods and a series of focused mid-latitude observations as requested by several external groups. The resultant data have been deposited in the CEDAR Madrigal database centered at Millstone Hill. This award provided significant operational support for the research activities of the Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences Group (AGS) at the MIT Haystack Observatory.  Over the lifetime of the grant, 94 scientific publications and 3 M.S./Ph.D. dissertations used Millstone Hill data or scientific analysis.  Scientific research topics covered a wide variety of processes in Earth's geospace environment, including key mid-latitude physics in the upper atmosphere, ionosphere-thermosphere coupling, magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling effects, and geospace storm response in the ionosphere and plasmasphere.

Support allowed the Haystack Observatory Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences group to continue its dedication to space science community service both inside and outside the Geospace Facilities program with a number of focused activities. As in recent years, many of these efforts are specifically targeted at enhanced inter-Facility collaborations, and serve academic courses, and active scientific collaborations with professors, undergraduates, and graduate students.  

These activities included an OpenRadar student-focused workshop in April 2017 involving 30+ students from Penn State [Prof. J. Urbina], Boston College, U. Mass. Lowell, and others. Hands-on activities for geospace software radar techniques (unique, to our knowledge) involved live radio hardware and software tutorials by MHGF staff and focused learning using cutting-edge radio science approaches.

The Millstone Hill ionospheric radar system uses the most powerful ground-based remote sensing technique of the terrestrial near-Earth space environment. As such, it has fundamental contributions to the welfare of our technologically dependent society by helping the NSF monitor conditions in the space environment and providing this information to the societal applied community.

Our extensive education and public outreach efforts also expose a large number of general public members both nationally and internationally to the value of science and also to the need to closely monitor our planet's environment. This helps STEM activities and generally motivates support for research.
